body_html:
@frankchn @alanyee @drpngx
I replaced logging_ops.scalar( _summary_key(head_name, mkey.LOSS), weighted_average_loss) _summary_key(head_name, mkey.LOSS), weighted_average_loss)

with the following statement.

tensorflow.summary.scalar( name=_summary_key(head_name, mkey.LOSS), tensor=weighted_average_loss,collections=None)

What I think the AssertionError: Element counts were not equal: is generated is due to the eval and loss is in the different graph according to author's comment on line 623-624.


# Uses the deprecated API to set the tag explicitly.
# Without it, training and eval losses will show up in different graphs.

If I am wrong then please give your suggestions.

body:
@frankchn @alanyee @drpngx 
I replaced `logging_ops.scalar(
          _summary_key(head_name, mkey.LOSS), weighted_average_loss)		          _summary_key(head_name, mkey.LOSS), weighted_average_loss)`
 
with the following statement.

 `tensorflow.summary.scalar(
        name=_summary_key(head_name, mkey.LOSS), tensor=weighted_average_loss,collections=None)`

What I think the` AssertionError: Element counts were not equal:` is generated is due to the eval and loss is in the different graph according to author's comment on line `623-624`.
```

# Uses the deprecated API to set the tag explicitly.
# Without it, training and eval losses will show up in different graphs.

```
If I am wrong then please give your suggestions.
